Beach Morphology Characteristics of Sea Turtle Nesting Sites: A Statistical Analysis

Beach Morphology Characteristics of Sea Turtle Nesting Sites: A Statistical Analysis 2022-04-26 By: Jordan Iserman Advisor: Dr. Samantha Seals An Undergraduate Proseminar In Partial Fulfillment of the Degree of Bachelor of Science in Mathematics The University of West Florida May 2022

Approval Page The Proseminar of Jordan Iserman is approved: ________________________________________________  __________ Samantha Seals, Ph.D., Proseminar Advisor          Date ________________________________________________  __________ Josaphat Uvah, Ph.D., Proseminar Committee Chair       Date Accepted for the Department: ________________________________________________  __________ Jia Liu, Ph.D., Department Chair              Date

Abstract The population of sea turtles has been decreasing over the last 30 years. This is a problem because the extinction of one species can cause ripple effects throughout the entire biosphere. The purpose of this report is to determine if there are statistically significant differences in beach characteristics between the nest line and the locations near the nest line in loggerhead and green turtles. Foreshore slope, beach slope, beach width, and foredune height were measured at the nest profile line and 25, 50, and 100 meters both east and west of the nest line. Paired t-tests and Wilcoxon signed-rank tests were performed to compare both the nest line to the other locations and the east to the west locations of the same distance from the nest line. 90% confidence intervals for the mean and median differences were constructed. Statistical significance was defined as \(\alpha = 0.1\)
Chapter 1 Introduction 1.1 Statement of Problem 1.2 Relevance of Problem 1.3 Literature Review

Chapter 1 Introduction 1.1 Statement of Problem As the population of sea turtles decreases, extinction becomes more of a possibility in the future. The loss of these turtles could threaten the overall biodiversity of the world. If the turtles go extinct, other species that rely on the turtles as food may experience a decrease in population. Other species that exist as food for the turtles will lose a predator and may experience an increase in population. The availability of nest sites for turtles has been declining, which is largely due to human activities, such as development in coastal areas and sea level rise as a result of climate change. The reduction of nest sites will result in less turtles nesting, which would lead to a further reduction of the population. This study examines beach morphological characteristics at and around the nest line to determine which variables are important to nest site selection. 1.2 Relevance of Problem Biodiversity is important because the loss of one species can have effects on multiple other species. One species may prey on another, while being prey for different species. If one species loses one of their major predators, their numbers can grow much higher. If a species loses a source of food, it is likely that there will be a reduction in the population of that species. A population change of one species will affect the populations of other species, and a chain reaction will occur. Humans may be involved as a link in this chain. 1.3 Literature Review There have been multiple studies that have attempted to model sea turtle nest site selection. A beach at El Cuyo, Mexico was examined to see if beach morphological characteristics influence probability of a site being used for nesting. Many variables affect nest-site selection, such as beach slope, orientation, width, oceanographic conditions, grain size, humidity, pH, temperature, and sand compression. They used Spearman correlation analyses between the number of nests in an area and the primary morphological characteristics. The total mean slope and the mean dune slope were able to explain 85.4% of the variability in beach profile. The correlation between total mean slope and berm slope was the only statistically significant (p < 0.05) correlation. Green turtle nest selection was negatively correlated with the berm slope (r = -0.67). Spearman correlation analyses were constructed to examine the effect of the beach slope and width on nest site selection. [1] Culver et al. attempted to model the probability of a nest being in a location using beach geomorphology characteristics. This study focuses on Kemps Ridley turtles. Generalized linear models were constructed to model nest site selection using elevation, distance from shoreline, maximum dune slope, and average beach slope. Elevation and distance from shoreline were the most influential variables in the models. Each variable was significant in every linear model (p < 0.001), and explained 40-46% of the variability. [2] A study done by Mortimer, J. was done to test if grain size of sand has an impact on nest site mortality, and to study nesting behaviors of sea turtles. Larger mean particle size is correlated with higher mortality. The number of trial nest holes and the mean particle diameter of sand were positively correlated using Spearman correlation (r = 0.815; p = 0.0001; n = 20). This study looked at green turtle nests and found that courser sands require more physiological effort for turtles to dig through. [3] A study by Provancha, J. and Ehrhart, L. looked at correlations between total emergences and beach morphological characteristics. Beach slope and total emergences were positively correlated (r = 0.86). It is stated that beach slope is correlated to multiple off-shore factors as well, so it is possible that turtles are using the off-shore characteristics to help them select a nesting site. [4] The goal of this study by Zavaleta-Lizarraga, L. and Morales-Mavil, J. was to determine the nesting variations of the green turtle. They tested the number of nests in different months of the year from June to September. Most of the nests were recorded in July and the least were recorded in September. There were not statistically significant differences between years, but there were between months (F = 4.45, p < 0.05). Certain beaches showed higher nesting probabilities (F = 14.07, p <0.01). Certain areas contained more nests. For example, the dune zone included 1206 nests, while the sandy beach zone contained 419 nests, and the tidal zone only contained 29. ANOVA was used for comparison in this study. [5]
Chapter 2 Methods 2.1 Data 2.2 Statistical Methods 2.3 Analysis of the Current Data 2.4 Analysis Results

Chapter 2 Methods 2.1 Data The sea turtle nest site data came from Pensacola beach in the summer of 2021. The data was recorded by Madison Williams using GPS technology. Data collection was guided and advised by Dr. Philip Schmutz for use by the Earth and Environmental Science department at the University of West Florida. 2.1.1 Variables The following variables were measured: Foreshore slope: Slope of the profile from the mean low water line to the mean high water line Beach slope: Slope of the profile from the mean high water line to the potential line of vegetation Beach width: Distance between the potential vegetation line and the mean high water line Foredune height: Highest elevation point between the landward dune boundary and the potential line of vegetation Figure 1 shows the a graphic to help visualize the variables Figure 1. Graphic of beach morphological characteristics. The variables were measured at the following locations: Nest line 25 meters west 25 meters east 50 meters west 50 meters east 100 meters west 100 meters east Figure 2 provides an image of the observed locations. Figure 2. Observed locations. 2.2 Statistical Methods 2.2.1 Paired T-Test Paired t-tests are used to compare two dependent means, which implies that observations are paired. Hypotheses \(H_{0}: \mu_{1} = \mu_{2}\) \(H_{1}: \mu_{1} \ne \mu_{2}\) Formula The formula to calculate \(t_{0}\) for a paired t-test is as follows: \[t_{0}=\frac{\overline{d}}{s_{d}/\sqrt{n}}\] \(\overline{d}\) is the average of the differences of the observations \(s_{d}\) is the sample standard deviation \(n\) is the sample size (number of pairs) Assumptions Observations are randomly selected Differences between pairs are approximately normally distributed No extreme outliers exist 2.2.2 Wilcoxon signed-rank test The Wilcoxon signed-rank test is used for dependent data that is not normally distributed. The Wilcoxon signed-rank test is performed by first calculating differences between each pair of data. The data is then ranked by absolute value. Hypotheses \(H_{0}: M_{D} = 0\) \(H_{1}: M_{D} \ne 0\) Test Statistic The formula to calculate \(T_{0}\) for the Wilcoxon signed-rank test is as follows: \[min(T_{+},|T_{-}|)\] \(T_{+}\) is the sum of the positive ranks \(T_{-}\) is the sum of the negative ranks Assumptions The random variable is continuous The probability density function of x is symmetric 2.2.3 Confidence Intervals Confidence intervals are used to calculate a range of values that are likely to obtain the true mean with a high degree of probability. Formula The formula for a confidence interval for \(\mu\) for dependent data is as follows: \[(\overline{d} - t_{\alpha/2}*\frac{s_{d}}{\sqrt{n}}, \overline{d} + t_{\alpha/2}*\frac{s_{d}}{\sqrt{n}})\] \(\overline{d}\) is the mean of the differences \(t_{\alpha/2}\) is the critical value 1 - \(\alpha\)/2 is the confidence level \(s_{d}\) is the standard deviation of the differences \(n\) is the sample size (number of pairs) The formula for a confidence interval for the median is as follows: \[(x_{j},x_{k})\] \(x_{j}\) and \(x_{k}\) are location statistics where \(x_{j}\) is the jth observation, and \(x_{k}\) is the kth observation \(j = n*q - z_{\alpha}\sqrt{n*q*(1-q)}\) \(k = n*q + z_{\alpha}\sqrt{n*q*(1-q)}\) \(n\) is the sample size (number of pairs) \(q\) is the quantile of interest, 0.5 is used for the median \(z_{\alpha}\) is the critical value \(\alpha\) is the significance level Interpretation The confidence interval is interpreted based on the significance level used. We can be \((1-\alpha)*100\)% confident that the true mean is between the calculated values. For example, a significance level of \(\alpha = 0.05\) and a confidence interval of \((0.15, 0.25)\) means that we are 95% confident that the true mean of the given values are between 0.15 and 0.25. 2.3 Analysis of the Current Data With the given set of data, the paired t-tests were appropriate. The data was approximately normally distributed, and no extreme outliers existed. Below are some of the quantile-quantile (QQ) plots used to assess normality (Figure 3). The rest of the QQ plots are included in the appendix. The Wilcoxon signed-rank test was also performed for comparison purposes. Foreshore slope, beach slope, beach width, and foredune height were all analyzed to find differences between locations. The nest lines were compared to every other location, 25W, 25E, 50W, 50E, 100W, 100E. Tests were also performed to compare each west variable with its respective east variable. Results for the paired t-test are shown as the mean with the corresponding confidence interval. Results for the Wilcoxon signed-rank test are shown as the median with the corresponding median confidence interval. Figure 3. Chapter 3 Conclusion The goal for this project was to perform statistical analysis on the sea turtle nest locations and determine if there is a statistically significant difference between these nest locations and the others. 3.1 Summary: Interpretation This analysis determined that statistically significant differences between the nest line and other locations exist. Foreshore slope differences exist between the nest line and 25E, 50E, 100E, and 100W, as well as between 50E and 50W. Beach Slope differences exist between the nest line and 25E, 25W, 50E, 50W, and 100W, as well as between 100W and 100E. Beach width differences exist between the nest line and 25W and 25E. No significant differences in foredune height were found between any variables. This analysis shows that foreshore slope and beach slope are important for nest site selection, while beach width and foredune height are relatively the same throughout the beach. 3.2 Limitations There were limitations for the project that may have affected results. The data was collected only on Pensacola Beach, which may or may not apply to other locations. The data also consisted of fourteen loggerhead turtle nests and one green turtle nest, which is an uneven balance of species. Inference cannot be made on green turtles due to the lack of sample size and thus, was excluded from analysis. Fourteen is also a relatively small sample size. A larger sample size will provide more accurate estimation, tighter confidence intervals, and the ability to perform more complex statistical analysis, such as modeling using regression analysis. Finally, this data only examines sea turtle nesting behavior for a single year; longitudinal data should be collected for a more complete picture of sea turtle preferences.
